characters: BACK TO FATHER BARRY, EDIE AND GROUP
TWO MORE PAIRS OF HEAVY FOOTSTEPS

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Shooting toward a small building (Hoboken Yacht Club) set floating about twenty-five yards off shore. A long, narro leads from the wharf to the shore, and on either side of large ocean liners which are being unloaded by arc light. is the glittering New York skyline. A great liner, blazin is headed down river. A ferry chugs across to Manhattan. counterpoint of ships' whistles, some shrill, others haun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the office of the longshoremen's local for this sec waterfront. Coming along the gangplank toward the shore i figure. He is TERRY MALLOY, a wiry, jaunty, waterfront ha late twenties. He wears a turtleneck sweater, a windbreak He whistles a familiar Irish song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching the shore and turning away from the union office burned-out piers. Turning up a waterfront tenement street lit by a dim stre throws an eerie beam. He is holding something inside his cannot see what it is.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Terry walks along until he reaches an ancient tenement wh hesitates, looks up toward the top of the building, and p fingers to his mouth lets out a shrill, effective whistle up the quiet street. Then he cups his hands to his mouth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Joey! Joey Doyle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window of a third-story room, from Terry's POV. JOEY youthful, rather sensitive and clean-cut Irish boy, pokes the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry? (then a little suspiciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey look- He reaches into his windbreaker in a gesture associated w gun from a shoulder holster. But instead he draws out a l pigeon. As he does so the bird makes an effort to escape wings, but Terry subdues it expertly and holds it up for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat uneasily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—one of yours. I recognized the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a fire escape in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Must be Danny-boy. I lost him in the last race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He followed my birds into their coop. Here, you want him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I got to watch myself these days. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring him up to your loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (some what reassured)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you on the roof. Joey closes the window and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Tensely, as if going through something he wishes he could looks in the direction of the tenement stoop and nods. No first time we see two men standing there under the doorwa was unable to see them from his window. When Terry nods t tenement hallway; he takes a few steps forward so as to b from Joey's widow. Then Terry raises the pigeon into the inexplicably, releases it. As it wings out of sight he tu up the street in the direction from which he came, walkin if trying to see the effect of what he has just done. A s one-armed longshoreman, MUTT MURPHY, staggers toward him, hoarse voice... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if it were a dirge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tippi-tippi-tim, tippi-tim, Tippi-tippi-tan, tippi-tan... (He stumbles into Terry.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta dime for a crippled-up docker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, beat it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dime, Terry, a dime for a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that coffee, you rummy. Now blow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for nothing, you bum. With a certain battered dignity, Mutt moves off, picking "Tippi-tippi-tan, tippi-tan... ." Terry takes an anxious toward the tenement.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: In the B.G. on the far shore is the New York skyline. In ship is being unloaded on this side of the river. In the of racing pigeons. Joey comes out on the roof and looks a door f rom the tenement stairway creaks open and Joey tur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry? There is no answer. Joey is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you, Terry? Two men step out upon the roof, their faces hidden in sha looks startled and retreats a  few steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Terry? The two men (BARNEY and SPECS) advance, silently. JOEY (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he'd meet me up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he realizes the intentions of the two men. He looks a means of escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Joey's angle. Moving in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a wild dash for the fire escape which leads him But when he reaches it, another goon, SLIM, appears, cutt escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey turns and runs along the edge of the roof, the illum in the B.G. He disappears from view as if he has jumped o ff the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rooftop is one floor lower than the rooftops on eith forming a trough between the two and providing no further escape for Joey. As Joey looks around desperately, Barney upper level and another goon, SONNY, appears on the other trapped between them. As they move forward he retreats ba the edge of the roof. JOEY (defiantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to jump so it looks like an accident? The assailants close in silently. Joey gestures them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. I'll take one of you with me. The goons edge in still closer, poker-faced, knowing they

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: An old-fashioned corner saloon with swinging doors. Stand corner, fl anked by a goon aptly named the TRUCK is CHARL Terry's older brother, rather handsome if a little too sm late thirties, a snappy dresser in his camel hair coat an hat. He is quick-witted and affable, more politician than Terry enters to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How goes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pigeon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resentfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you said. It worked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Terry, tapping his own temple)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That brother of yours is thinkin' alla time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the time. There is a short, shrill, almost human cry of a boat whis changes slightly in pitch and we are hearing an actual cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurtling off roof, with a bloodcurdling shriek.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: She screams.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Worried as he begins to wonder what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid somebody fell off a roof. Terry stares at him. Longshoremen come running out of the the sound of the scream. Terry has to struggle not to be with them. He works his way toward Charley, standing on t Truck, calmly watching the Friendly Bar customers excited past him. (Calls and commotion in the distance O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought he was gonna sing for the  Crime Commission.   He won't. Truck winks at Charley significantly. Terry catches the m horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said they was only going to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they'd talk to him. Try to get him to dummy up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he gave them an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured the worst they'd do is work him over a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably gave 'em an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost primly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been giving our boss a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't a bad little fella, that Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talkative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't a bad little fella ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he could sing, but he couldn't fly. Terry looks at Truck, stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetically, nodding toward bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kid. I'll buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute. Charley looks at him, slightly concerned, and goes in wit watches the longshoremen hurrying past him, in the direct

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Forming a circle around Joey are KAYO NOLAN, a hard littl man; TOMMY COLLINS, a young longshoreman friend of Joey's giant Negro; MOOSE, a good-natured, hulking longshoreman; The shot favors POP DOYLE, a short , stocky man with a sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to someone running up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kept tellin' him: don't say nothin', keep quiet, you'll live longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to another cop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the ambulance to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF ONLOOKERS
dialogues.text: Including a hard-faced longshoreman, a careworn woman in thirties (Mrs. Collins) and Mutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't gonna need no ambulance. FATHER BARRY, a lean, tough, West Side priest, climbs a w and approaches the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roughly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One side. Le'me through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Father Barry as he passes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same thing they did to my Andy five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: BODY OF JOEY
dialogues.text: Father Barry prays. A police sergeant turns to Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Pop Doyle, aren't you, the boy's father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fell over backward from the roofВ— like he was pushed. Any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggressively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the one longshoreman with guts enough to talk to them crime investigators. Everybody knows that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling angrily and pushing her away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who asked you. Shut your trap. If Joey'd taken that advice he wouldn't beВ— (starts to crack up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody know that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm an honest cop. Give me some leads and I'll... Pop stands silently, choked with grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ListenВ— don't bother him. Right, Moose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I learnedВ— all my life on the waterfrontВ— dont ask no questionsВ— don't answer no questions. Unless you... . (looks at the body and stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reverently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was all heart, that boy. Enough guts for a regiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a bitter rage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GutsВ— I'm sick of guts. He gets a book in the pistol local and right away he's gonna be a hero. Gonna push the mob off the dock singlehanded... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comfortingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Pop. I know it's rough but time and faith are great healers... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey's sister, a fresh-faced, sensitive young Irish girl kneeling over the body. She looks up and around at the Fa grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time and faith... . My brother's dead and you stand there talking drivel about time and faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Edie, IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plunging on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could anyone do this to Joey. The best in the neighborhood... . everybody said it, not only me. Who'd want to harm Joey? Tell meВ— who?  -- who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I knew, Edie, ButВ— (starts to turn away as if appealing to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't turn away! Look at it! You're in this tooВ— don't you see, don't you see? You're in this too, Father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively, sincerely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edie, I do what I can. I'm in the church when you need me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In the church when you need me." Was there ever a saint who hid in the Church? She turns from him angrily, toward the covered form of Jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Barry stands there jolted and troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves in to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive her, Father. Them two was as close as twins. Father Barry nods. Thinking hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever was in on this'll burn in hell until kingdom come... .

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is the sharpest possible contrast to the s is a rough waterfront bar full of half-gassed longshoreme boys. They are all watching a fight on TV above the  bar, much hoarse laughter and ad lib jokes at the fight. The o watching is Terry, who sits at a table by himself staring at a hal glass of beer. Mutt is wandering around in the B.G.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Terry, Riley's makin' a bum outa that SolariВ— Terry looks off and seesВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unconcernedly drinking and enjoying the fight. SPECS Come have a shot. Still disturbed and preoccupied, Terry shakes his head an through the bar toward the  back room. Others call to him but he keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A partition separates this room from the main bar, and a of the bar extends through the partition. On the wall are posters and some pictures of fighters, ball players and h table, flanked by Charley and a tall, muscular bodyguard, JOHNNY FRIENDLY. He is not tough in a conventional way, b sinister intent, a humorless sense of domination that is dangerous. The boxing match can be seen on a smaller TV s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it off. Them clowns can't fight. There's nobody tough anymore. JOCKO, the bartender, pokes his head through the archway bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, boss, Packy wants another one on the cuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a generous wave of his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to him! As Johnny finishes off a bottle of beer, BIG MAC, the bul boss, comes up to the table with a thick roll of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the cut from the shape-up. Eight hundred  and ninety-one men at three bucks a head makesВ— puts on glasses, incongruous on his beefy face --twenty-six seventy-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Charley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, you count it. Countin' makes me sleepy. Terry enters during the above and sits at the bar, broodi glad to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H'ya, slugger, how they hangin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (subdued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So-so, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pantomiming, defending against blows)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hit me, now, don't hit me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a banana boat at forty-six tomorra.  If we pull a walkout it might be a few bucks  from the shippers. Them bananas go bad in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll ask ten G. (looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Morgan? Where's that big banker of mine? As Johnny talks he holds on to Terry, and fondles him cas a big-eared, large-nosed little weasel of a man, pokes hi door as if he were waiting just outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mockingly В— Morgan is sort of court jester)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, J.P., how's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Havin' trouble with Kelly again, boss. He Won't take no loans and Big Mac puts him to work anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting at J.P.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my wife's nephew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right back at Big Mac)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he don't take no loans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to give him work. She'd murda me... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I stay single. (turns to Johnny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the interest on the day, boss. Five thirty two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it from him and handing it to Sonny)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count it. Now Sonny and Charley are both counting. SKINS, another r mob, a nervous, pasty-faced man, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, SkinsВ— (as Skins approaches Johnny lowers his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --get away with that sheet metal all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, that new checker faked the receipt. Here it is, boss. (offers receipt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stow the receipt. I'll take the cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (producing another roll of bills)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Terry, sulking at the bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Terry, front and center. Terry comes over reluctantly and Johnny hands him the bil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you know I don't like to count, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good for you. Develops your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What mind? He starts to laugh but Johnny stops him with a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. I like the kid. (tweaks Terry's cheek fondly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the night he took Farella at St. Nick's, Charley. We won a bundle. Real tough. A big try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops counting and taps his nose proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a dent. (tweaks his nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, rubs Terry's head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My favorite little cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disconcerted as he tries to count)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-sixВ— sevВ— aah I lost the count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tolerantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OKВ— skip it, Einstein. How come you never got no education like the rest of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (good-naturedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only arithmetic he got was hearing the referee count up t ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hot-tempered, starting to attack Big Mac)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, MacВ— Johnny laughs and pulls Terry back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gives with our boy tonight, Charley? He ain't himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if Terry were not there)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Joey Doyle thing. You know how he is. Things like thatВ— he exaggerates them. Too much Marquis of Queensbury.  It softens 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the money from Sonny, Skins and J.P. and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dealing out some bills to each of them as if the money  werecards, while Charley goes on counting) Listen kid, I'm a soft tough too. Ask any rummy  on the  dock if I'm not good for a fin any time they put the arm on me (then more harshly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my old lady raised us ten kids on a stinkin' watchman's pension. When I was sixteen I had to beg for work in the hold. I didn't work my way up out of there for nuthin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sorry to have aroused JohnnyВ— who speaks loud and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with frightening force when stung) I know, Johnny, I know... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takin' over this local, you know it took a little doin'. Some pretty tough fellas were in the way. They left me thisВ— (suddenly holds up chin to show a long ugly scar on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: neck) В—to remember them by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he got up and chased them they thought it was a dead man coming after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Terry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what's eatin' you, kid. But I got two thousand dues-payin' members in my localВ— that's seventy-two thousand a year legitimate and when each one of 'em puts in a couple of bucks a day to make sure they work steadyВ— well, you figure it out. And that's just for  openers. We got the fattest piers in the fattest harbor in the  world. Everything that moves in and outВ— we take our cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why shouldn't we? If we c'n get it we're entitled to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't robbin' pennies from beggars. We cuttin' ourselves in for five-six million a year just on our half a dozen piersВ—  a drop in the bucket compared to the traffic in the harbor.  But a mighty sweet little  drop, eh, Charley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wisely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So look, kid, you don't think we c'n afford to be boxed o of a deal like thisВ— a deal I sweated and bled forВ— on account of one lousy little cheese-eater, that Doyle  bum, who thought he c'd go squealin' to the Crime Commission?  Do you?В— Terry is uncomfortably silent. Johnny raises his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, Johnny, I just thought I should've been told if

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing back the money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make it twentysix twenty-three. You're fifty short,  Skins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning darkly on Skins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IВ— I musta counted wrong, boss, IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme. He reaches over and takes money out of Skins's pockets, s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come from Green Point? Go back to Green Point. You don't work here no more. (impulsively he hands the bill to TerryВ— smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, kid, here's half a bill. Go get your load on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still troubled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, thanks, Johnny, I don't want it, IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roughly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go onВ— a little present from your Uncle Johnny. (He pushes the bill into the breast pocket of Terry's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: jacket, then  turns to Big Mac) And Mac, tomorra mornin' when you shape the men put Terry in the loft. Number one. Every day. (to Terry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice easy work. Check in and goof off on the coffee bags. O.K.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Johnny... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a kind of warning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a real friend here, kid. Don't forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should he forget it? As Terry turns away, toward the bar,

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Terry, darkly troubled, is watching the pigeons he has ju

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY CONNERS,
dialogues.text: a freckle-faced fourteen-year-old boy, approaches along t stretch of roof seen in the mugging of Joey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! Terry turns around startled, as Jimmy comes climbing up o trough where Joey was trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—I was gonna feed 'em, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 's all right, kid. I took care of 'em myself this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you must've been up early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he hardly slept)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I was awake anyway so I figuredВ— (gesturestoward feeding pigeons; then with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: admiration)  They got it made. Eat all they wantВ— fly around like cra sleep side by sideВ— and raise gobs of squabs. O.S. or in B.G. a ship coming into port sounds its whistl him back to reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get over there.  (O.S. sound of ship whistle again. Terry answers the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ship irritably)  O.K., O.K., I'm coming. (starts off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't spill no water on the floor now. I Don't want them birds to catch cold. Jimmy signals the Golden Warrior saluteВ— the first two f together. Terry answers with the same salute as he goes o disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Some three hundred men are standing around, men of all si some in dungarees, some in baggy denims, wearing battered or service discards, and either caps or woolen pullovers. of Negroes. A ship is berthing in the B.G. The mood is so restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muttering to each other.   AD LIBS He was a good boy, the Doyle kid. Sure he was, th got it in the head. Couldn't learn to keep his mouth shut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his chum, JACKIE, as another pal, CHICK, comes up. T around as if t rying to hear what the men are muttering b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jackie but really to Terry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jackie, what D'ya think of this privileged character? Don't have to shape up no more. Got himself a soft touch up in the loft. (mimics sound of snoring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks at Jackie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waterfront Western Union. (business of putting his hand to his mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks around at the restless men again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doin' lovely, Terry, very lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., O.K., That's enough. In the B.G. Pop can be seen approaching Nolan, Moose, Tom Luke with a windbreaker jacket over his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little hurt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter wit' you, success gone to ya head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you lay off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chick in a falsetto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ain't we touchy this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nolan, Moose, Tommy, Luke, and others are muttering about comes up to them. The  men quickly drop the subject of Jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Pop. The lads who get work Today'll be chippin' in gladly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, we'll take care of ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the truth, Pop. Others mutter expressions of bitter sympathy.  "Tough abo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, boys, but I'm gonna shape. Who do you think's gonna pay for the funeralВ— Johnny Friendly and the boss stevedore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reacting.  Sonny, a few feet away, also hears and we foll Pop and group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watch that talk. What you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just tellin' me how proud he was to belong to a fine honest local run by such an outstandin' labor leader as Johnny Friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get wise now, you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wise! If I was wise I wouldn't be no longshoreman for thirty years and poorer now than when I started. Sonny looks at him threateningly. Nolan holds his ground on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HereВ— I brought you Joey's windbreakerВ— Wear it, Kayo. Yours is more full of holes than The Pittsburgh infield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is affected, but largely hiding his feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.P. Morgan pops up right behind Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condolences. How you fixed for cabbage this mornin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh me and my chum are just rolling in the stuff. We only work down here for a hobby, J.P. (Pop's cronies chuckle.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haw, haw, hawВ— that's a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undaunted, to Pop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be needing a few dollars for your extras, Won't you, Pop? You're three weeks behind on the last twenty-five, but I'm willing to take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some chance at ten percent a week! And if he don't borrow, he don't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ought to belt you one, J.P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (retreating slightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise a hand to me and... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... .and you'll tell Johnny Friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be off the pier for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ashamed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, slip me a billВ— and may you rot in hell, J.P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm dead 'n gone you'll know what a friend I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop dead now, why don't you, so we c'n test your theory? Moose leads the laughter. J.P. looks at them sourly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condolences. J.P. goes off with his shoulders bent over and his head d mournful bird, and Nolan walks behind him, mimicking.  No Pop isn't laughing and stops.  CAMERA FOLLOWS J.P. toward and Jackie and holds on them. Two men in business suitsВ— carrying a briefcase, looking decidedly out of place on t approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (larger, more good-natured of the two)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do any of you men know Terry Malloy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malloy? Never heard of 'im.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither They both turn away sullenly. Glover and his colleague, G at Terry carefully. Gillette is scrappy and tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Terry Malloy, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspiciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I recognized you. Saw you fight in St. Nick's a couple of years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K. O.K. Without the bird seed. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our identification. He snaps out his wallet and holds it open for Terry's ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WaterfrontВ— CrimeВ— CommissionВ— ? (pushes wallet back indignantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're getting ready to hold public hearings on waterfront crime and underworld infiltration of longshore unions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (automatically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't heard the questions yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rumor that you're one of the last  people to see Joey Doyle alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I still sayВ— I don't know nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not accusing you of anything, Mr. Malloy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We only want to ask you a few things about people you may know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People IВ— You mean sing for you. Get out of here before IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight but confident smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't advise that, Mr. Malloy. Unless you want to be booked for assaulting an officer of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't know nothing, I didn't see nothing, I ain't saying nothing. So why don't you and your girlfriend get lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Malloy, you have a right not to talk,  if that's what you choose to do. But the public  has a right to know the facts, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding in agreement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may be seeing you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never will be much too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost like a friend)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. The two men nod and turn away. Jackie and Chick, a few pa been taking it in. Terry swaggers for their benefit .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like them jokers? Taking me for a pigeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking the investigators, in a falsetto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the names, I'll write 'em down in me little book. Chick laughs and punches Terry's arm with rough affection

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (responding to the praise)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more word 'n I would've belted the two of 'em,  badge or no badge! They nod and laugh approvingly. There is a blast from the B.G. which is just docking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hiring boss. A stevedore official comes up to him wit slips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the tabs for two hundred banana carriers. Big Mac blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to cheer Pop up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A banana boat. It would be bananas.  One of these days me ship's comin' in from Ireland,  God love 'er, loaded to the gunnels with sweet Irish whiskey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nolan, me lad, ye're dreamin' again. They laugh, then Pop looks O.S. and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—Edie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Pop's POV. Talking to a pier guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing with Kayo. About to start forward when the shape blows, restraining him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kayo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the devil is she doin' down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a brogue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edie, I know your father well, and I'm sorry for  your troubles. But there's been hundreds of  murders down here and practically no convictionsВ— hardly any arrests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Mr. Rourke? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last fellow who talked was awful dead  when they pulled him out of the river. I guess  the Sisters don't teach you things like that up at your school in Tarrytown.  (with a gesture of futility)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the waterfront. He shrugs his helplessness and turns away. Edie stands cr Then she turns in the opposite direction away from the pi

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Father Barry is approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Barry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Edie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I spoke out of turn last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm just a gravy-train rider in  a turned-around collar? She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you?  (with humor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the Sisters taught you not to lie. She smiles in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about your question and the answer come up and hit meВ—  bang. This is my parish. I don't know how much I can do but you're right, EdieВ— I'll never find out if I don't come down here and take a good look for myself. She looks at him hopefully. O.S. a whistle blows again, s turn in its direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting his whistle away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting silently, hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following men report to the loftВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malloy. Terry steps forward. Hendricks, Krajowski. Now, two hundred banana carriers. He approaches the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching from the slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop never talks about this. Father Barry watches interestedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men press closer to Big Mac, each one trying to attra attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't crowd me. Stand back.

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD MAN
dialogues.text: (seedy, toothless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a break, Mac. I been  two weeks out of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got five kids. I need a day bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (old-fashioned looking in his knit stocking cap and heavy wool sweater)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about me, Mac? I knew your old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (roughly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you bums, push back. I'll do the pickin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Big Mac's angle. One touches an earВ—another strokes another begs with his  yesВ—hungry, pleading, desperate f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angrily trying to clear the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give four bucks for the job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kick in five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving them hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back! Get back! The beefy longshoreman actually makes a grab for one of t men begin to surround and engulf Mac. He is jostled and p beefy longshoreman, slightly behind Mac, suddenly knocks tabs out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperately over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sonny! Truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred and fifty men scrambling on the ground, fight tabs like animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrified, as they watch the struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he begins to rise, tab in hand, a big longshoreman at taller swings a vicious punch at him. Kayo, with old-time "slips" it by a fraction of an inch. The effect could be comedy relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the groundВ—as he is about to pick up a tab, a heavy s his hand and the tab is grabbed away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop!

dialogues.speaker: FREE-FOR-ALL FAVORING POP
dialogues.text: Pop is battling near the edge of the free-for- all, in vi Father Barry. He sees a tab on the ground and is about to when another man only slightly younger and bigger punches nose. He retaliates with a looping punch that knocks his back; but he is unable to scoop up the tab because meanwh Terry's has called over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Terry. Grab me on! Terry reaches for it with one hand while blocking Pop off He calls over to a crony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, Jackie boy. As he hands it over to his chum, Pop comes charging in at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, give me that. He swings wild punches at Terry. Just then Luke, the burl longshoreman, sees a tab behind Pop, hurls himself toward Pop with him, and back into the battle royal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has seen the above action and makes a beeline for Ter furious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that. It belongs to Pop. He saw it first. Terry is enjoying himself. Unconsciously Edie is pressing against him to get the tab and her rage is a kind of pass pleases him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought you was gonna go to workВ— with all them muscles. (winks at Jackie, who laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to meВ— my Pop's jobВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes him so special?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jackie; handing him the tab)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things 're lookin' up on the docks, huh, Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you recognize him, dopey. That's Old Man Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing his bravado)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle. (looks around at Pop, the identity hitting him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey Doyle's... .? (stares at Edie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... .You're his... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister. Yes I am. He runs his hand over his face and then, with a sudden im

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to lug bananas in the rain anyway, do you, Jackie? He reaches over and takes the tab back from Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah, give it to 'im. Terry hands the slip to Edie and adds, for the benefit of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go, muscles. Nice wrastlin' with you. He flexes his forearm and throws two quick jabs at an ima opponent, a characteristic gesture. He sets his cap at a and winks at his chums but we feel his manner is forced, his guilt. Edie looks after him with smoldering anger. She turns as Father Barry comes into view, leading Pop. P bleeding and he is pretty thoroughly battered. Nolan join

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brusquely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, just the beakВ— (taps his nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been busted before. Edie hands him the tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HereВ—I got it for you. Pop takes it, but he is humiliated, and bitter that she s in this moment of weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I can use itВ— (glares at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go back to the Sisters where you belong. (His anger mounting with his need to regain

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his self-respect, he turns on Father Barry.) I'm surprised with you, Father, if you don't mind my sayin' so. Lettin' her see things ain't fit for the eyes of a decent girl. Just then Big Mac shouts from the pier opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Doyle, you got a tab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding it up angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then get in there. Number three gang, number one hatch, puh-ronto. Pop jumps and hurries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following Pop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our welfare officer. He's been away three times for assault and battery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching him go. Around them are at least one hundred rej linger in resentful silence. Some of them are rubbing han the melee. A truck, hurrying into the pier, sounds its ho men barely avoid being run down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily, to the rejected group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outa the way. Come back tomorra. Father Barry looks at all this in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to one rejected man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do now? The man shrugs, too beaten down to answer. Father Barry a What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like he says. Come back tomorra. Luke goes along with Father Barry, who approaches Moose a have also been rejected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what you do, just take it like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully looking around and lowering his voice matter-of-factly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five straight mornin's I been Standin' here and the bum looks right through me. There's always a couple hundred left standin' in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undertone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh. Sonny's over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's nothing you can do? How about your union?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an undertone) You know how a blackjack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: local works, Father. Get up in a meetin', make a motion, the lights go out, you go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If three guys talk on a corner, Johnny'sВ— (He takes a careful look around.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—boys break us up. Look at 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't the minersВ— sailorsВ— garment workersВ— get rid of this years ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waterfront's tougherВ— like it ain't part of America. Anywhere else you got the law protectin' ya. Here ya just get knocked off and forgotten. LikeВ— (He stops.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, not here, across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: River Street, you might as well be inВ— Sonny and Truck move in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, a church picnic? Get outa here. Excuse me, Father. They all start away from the pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking to see if he is out of earshot)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how it's been ever since Johnny and his cowboys took over the local.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name one place where it's even safe to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impulsively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a significant pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottom of the church. Father Barry has spoken in a normal voice,as contrasted w whispering of the others, and they all look off toward So to see if they have heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching them suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in an undertone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you're letting yourself in for, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a cigarette on you? (As he is given one, he looks off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Father Barry's angle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice decisive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me boys. Use the bottom of the church. Father Barry looks at Edie.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: In this long area atop the working pier various articles stored. Elderly men work at a leisurely pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On top of which Terry is lying comfortably reading a comi Charley enters to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working hard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a living. He wriggles himself deeper into the coffee bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind working once in a while to justify this lofty position?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just fnished work. I counted the bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a little extra detail for you. The local priest and this Doyle girl are getting up a meeting in the church. We'd like a rundown on it. You know, names and numbers of all the players. You're nominated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me, Charley? I'd feel funny going in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating this job)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny does you favors, kid. You got to do a little one for him once in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But going in that church, I'd be stooling for you, Charley. You make a pigeon out of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tolerantly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain you something, kid. Stooling is when you rat on your friends, on the guys you're with. (sees Terry frown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Johnny needs a favor, don't try to figure it out, just do it. Now go ahead, join the congregation.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: This is an overflow chapel for the church above. There ar glass windows, an altar, pews and the figures of saints, utter simplicity; it has not lost its basement feeling, a unadorned walls and low lighting may suggest the catacomb The above is seen from the POV of Terry as he approaches. Barry faces a small group of longshoremen still in their including Nolan, Moose, Tommy, and Luke; Edie sits behind faced, rather ascetic-looking priest, FATHER VINCENT, sit disapprovingly in the rear. As Terry stands in the rear, enter, Father Barry is saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapidly, with a cigarette in his mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought there'd be more of you here, butВ— the Romans found out what a handful could do, if it's the right handful. And the same goes for you and the mob that's got their foot on your neck. I'm just a potato-eater but isn't it simple as one - two thre OneВ— The working conditions are bad. TwoВ— They're bad because the mob does the hiring. ThreeВ— The only way to break the mob is to stop letting them get away with murder. (He looks around at them. Everybody is silent,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: waiting.) If just one of you would answer one question, we'd have a start. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that question isВ— Who killed Joey Doyle?

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Silence. Moose looks down at the floor. Nolan works his l the palm of his right hand. Tommy runs his hand over his embarrassed. Luke stares straight ahead of him. Terry set stubbornly. Edie looks at all of them with a hopeful, ple intensity. Father Barry waits, and then asks againВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one of you has a line onВ— who killed Joey Doyle? Silence. I've got a hunch every one of you could tell us something about it. Silence. Then answer this oneВ— How can we call ourselves Christians and protect these murderers with our silence? Silence. The Father looks from one to the other, hoping f in the ranks. Terry starts down the aisle, just as Edie t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy Collins, you were Joey's best friend. How can you just sit there and not be saying anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll always think of him as my best friend, butВ— He falls silent and shakes his head. Next to him, Nolan n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to Moose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who asked him here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Terry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. I'm trying to find out just what happened to Joey Doyle. Maybe you can help. Terry is tight-lipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering loudly to Moose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brother of Charley the Gent. They'll help us get to t bottom of the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turnsaround angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep Charley out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spunkily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think he'd beВ— helpful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insolently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ask him, why don't you ? Ask him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I willВ— one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs scornfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days. They glare at each other. Edie regards Terry with curiosi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting through)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, if you know who the pistols are, if you see them on the dock every day, are you going to keep still until they cut you down one by one? (turns from one to the other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you? Are you? How about you, Nolan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father, one thing you got to understand. On the dock we've always been D 'n D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D 'n D?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deef 'n dumb. Somethin' c'n happen right in front of our noses and we don't see nothin'. You know what I mean. No matter how much we hate the torpedoes we don't rat. Moose, Luke, and others mutter agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, get smart. I know you're Getting' pushed around but one thing we got in this country is ways of fightin' back. Getting' the facts to the public. Testifyin' for what you know is right against what you know is wrong. What's ratting to them is telling the truth for you. Can't you see that? (turns from one to another)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Huh? The men do not respond. A few look back at Terry apprehen Barry subsides, feeling defeated. Father Vincent comes fo takes over the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seems to be just about all we can do at this time, I think you'll agree, Father, and so I'd like to close with a few words from St. Paul, "Come unto me... ." He is interrupted by the shattering of glass as a rock co through the long narrow stained-glass window. Everyone looks at each other Some jump up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thumbing toward the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at Edie; then he cases the room for other exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you about sticking your neck out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These fellers need help, Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (striding off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Don't blame me when they pack you off to Abyssinia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances. (turnstoward the group, picking up the rock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must be on the right track or they wouldn't be sending us this little calling card. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got a cigarette? (as he takes one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better go home in pairs. They all start out tensely, Father Barry helping to pair the door. Edie lingers behind them, frightened. As she st Terry suddenly approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that way. She looks at him in surprise. Terry pulls her back with r solicitousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, I'll get you out. Before she has time to protest he is leading her rapidly exit.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Moose and Nolan come down the steps of the church. They d they are being ambushed but the audience does. The goons them, and we see the effect of this action in the giant s the face of the church, the flailing bats looming as larg poles. We hear the cries of pain, then groans.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: As Father Barry runs up, Sonny and Truck are working Nola baseball bats. Father Barry wrestles with them, taking a in consequence, and the goons take off. Nolan sinks to th with blood streaming from his head and Father Barry kneel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Nolan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, considerin' they was usin' my head for a baseball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a handkerchief to blot the blood on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nolan's face) Nice fellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing his head angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those blood suckers. How I'd love to fix those babies butВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you still hold out for silence? Nolan hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still call it ratting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you on the level, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I stick my neck out, and they chopped it off, would that be the end of it? Or are you ready to go all the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go down the line, Kayo, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball batsВ— that's just for openers. They'll put the muscle on you, turned-around collar or no turned-around collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I still say you stand up and I'll stand up with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down to the wire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So help me God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I had my fun, I've drunk my fill and I tickled some good-lookin' filliesВ— I'm on borried time. Nolan says this with a slight smile as he makes an effort

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he helps Nolan to his feet with a grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're off and running, Kayo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Vincent is nervously closing the doors.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Leading down to a dark side street. Terry pulls Edie alon pace. He jumps down from the bottom landing, then looks u her, for whom the height is too great. He holds her for a he stops and listens. Heavy rapid footsteps approach. It Luke, closely followed by goons wielding baseball bats. T Edie back against the wall into the shadows. The goons run past and Terry starts racing with narrow alley in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one that meets the alley at the other end. As Terry r street with Edie, he looks around to be sure all's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're O.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steel pipes and baseball bats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They play pretty rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which side are you with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straightening her dress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get home all right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better see you get there. She looks at him wonderingly. The rummy longshoreman, Mut shuffles over toward Edie with his hand out, frightening Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dime. One thin dime for a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee, that's a laugh. His belly is used to nothing but rotgut whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Terry and coming closer to Edie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One little dime you don't need. (He brings his whiskered, sodden face very close to Edie's and stares at her as if

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: througha dense fog.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know youВ— you're Edie Doyle. Your Brother's a saintВ— (crosses himself quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В–only one ever tried to get me my compensation. He points a wavering (unconsciously accusing) finger at T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, Terry, you was there the night he was'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking at Terry in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously reaching into his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeahВ— Here's half a buck, go have yourself a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe itВ— a small fortune. (He kisses the coin, then pulls from his shirt a small tobacco pouchful of coins in which he deposits this one.) (then turns on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry again) You can't buy meВ— you're still a bum! (raises his cap to Edie with unexpected formality)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Edie. Lord have mercy on Joey. (crosses himself quickly and he goes off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sourly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who says bum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking after Mutt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody loved Joey. From the little kids to the old rummies. (looks up at Terry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know him very well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evasively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody knew him. He got around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking after Mutt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did that man mean when he said you were... .?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah, he's a bottlebaby, he talks to himself, the joke of the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at him and then hurrying her steps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get home. She gives Terry as wide a berth as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid of me. I ain't going to bite you. She continues to walk apart from him. What's the matter, they don't let you walk with fellers where you've been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how the Sisters are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You training to be a nun or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a regular college. It's just run by the nuns. The Sisters of St. Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you spend all your time just learning stuff, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling at the way he puts it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be a teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teacher! Dong!!! (He's impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I admire brains. Take my brother Charley. He's very brainy. Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't brains. It's how you use them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (increasingly impressed, almost awestruck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah. I get your thought. You know I seen you lots of times before. Parochial school on Pulaski Street? Seven, eight years ago? Your hair come down inВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In braids? That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looked like two pieces of rope. And your teeth wereВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I thought I'd never get those braces off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you were a mess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get home all right from hereВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thought I'm tryin' to get over is you grew up beauteeful. Remember me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strutting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people got faces that stick in your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember you were in trouble all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you got me! It's a wonder I wasn't punchy by the time I was twelve. The rulers those Sisters used to whack me with! (cracks himself on the head and laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They thought they could beat an education into meВ—I foxe 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they just didn't know how to handle you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warming to the subject)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you've done it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little more patience and kindness. That's what makes people mean and difficult. Nobody cares enough about them. Terry plays "Hearts and Flowers" on an imaginary violin. curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me while I reach for my beads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-what? Where you been the last four five years? Outer space?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Mother died Pop sent me out to school in the country. He was afraid with no one home I'dВ— get into bad company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (righteously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he played it smart. Too many good-for-nothin's around here. All they got on their mind's a little beer, a little pool, a littleВ— (looks at her and catches himself, his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: registering: I'm with a Nice Girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get you home.

dialogues.speaker: EXT TENEMENT SUNDAY AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Overhead a flock of pigeons sweep by, close enough for th their wings to be heard. Terry and Edie approach the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, they sure fly nice, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like pigeons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my own flock up there, getting their evening workout. I won plenty of races with 'em. (impulsively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you want to see them? Come up on the roof with me and I'll show 'em to you. They have reached the stoop of Edie's tenement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not wanting to let go of her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only live up there and across the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Edie, am I going to see you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know. Then she goes in abruptly. Terry is left standing there, her, confused by the unfamiliar emotion he is feeling for his thoughts are interrupted byВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a lower- floor window opening as Mrs. Collin head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got some nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overhearing, as she enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. Leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was only talkin' to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's off limits for bums like you. Leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can look at her, can't I? It's a free country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that free. She closes window.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: She mounts the stairs, thinking about what she has just h close on her face, as she approaches the door to their pl

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: As Edie enters, Pop, in his undershirt, favorite attire, putting the last articles into Edie's suitcase. He snaps shut. There is an old cat on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all packed. (reaches into his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's your bus ticket. You're on your way back to St. Anne's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, I'm not ready to go back yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edie, for years we pushed quarters into a cookie jar, to keep you up there with the Sisters, and to keep you from things like I just seen out the window. My own daughter arm-in-arm with Terry Malloy. You know who Terry Malloy is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimics)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he! Edie, you're so softhearted and soft-headed you wouldn't recognize the devil if he had you by the throat. You know who this Terry Malloy is? The kid brother of Charlie the Gent, Johnny Friendly's right hand, a butcher in a camel hair coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me Terry is too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to tell you he's Little Lord Fauntleroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to act tough, but there's a look in his eyes that... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look in his eyes! Hold your hats, brother, here we go again. You think he's one of those cases you're always draggin' in and feelin' sorry for. Like the litter of kittens you hadВ—the only one she wants to keep has six toes and it's cockeyed to boot. Look at him. The bum! And the crush you had on that little Abyssinian... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't Abyssinian, Pop, Assyrian... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six-toed cats. Assyrians. Abyssinians. It's the same difference. Well don't think this Terry Malloy is any six-toed cockeyed Assyrian. He's a bum. Charley and Johnny Friendly owned him when he was a fighter and when they ring the bell he still goes into action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted to see me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think we kept you out in Tarrytown just to have you go walkin' with a corner saloon hoodlum like Terry Malloy? Now get back to Tarrytown, before I put a strap to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And learn about charity and justice and all the other things people would rather talk about than practice? Pop goes up to her and holds out his two arms, his right one closer to Edie; he trembles with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See this arm? It's two inches longer 'n the other one. That's years of workin' and sweatin', liftin' and swingin' a hook. And every time I heisted a box or a coffee bag I says to myselfВ—this is for Edie, so she can be a teacher or somethin' decent. I promised your mother. You better not let her down. Suddenly touched, Edie goes up to Pop and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, don't think I'm not feeling grateful for all you've done to get me an education and shelter me from this. (becoming aroused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now my eyes are open. I see things I know are so wrong how can I go back and keep my mind on things that are only in books and that people aren't living? I'm staying, Pop. And I'm going to keep on trying to find out who's guilty for Joey. I'd walk home with a dozen Terry Malloys if I thought they could help me. I tell you I'm staying, Pop. Pop starts to pull his belt out of his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are likeВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with regret and affection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop! She turns and runs out. Pop with his belt in one hand, ta steps after her and then stops and stares at the unused b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head as he mutters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary and Joseph, keep an eye on her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Autumn on the roof. It is not particularly romanticВ—ther clotheslines, wooden boxes, etc. But to the people of thi it is a luxurious terrace. Terry's birds are aloft, flyin circle, nicely silhouetted against the sun-drenched eveni Conners is with him. Terry has a long pole with which he keeps the birds circl leaning against the wall, playing an Irish melody on his wife, a heavyset woman, sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Moving her feet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My feet feels like dancin'. But the rest of me just feels like settin' here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he swings his pole he looks off and seesВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurrying toward him across the rooftops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catching sight of her, and stopping to admire her as she him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jimmy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
